column4: Does anyone know where I can change the graphics card from board-integrated to my other card?
travis: its in the bios for my bios, but once it gets to the OS it changes
I did it on SuSe in YAST, is there anything like that on Ubuntu?
How would I go about changing hardware settings such as what graphics card is used?
double check the bios and make sure you booting to AGP not PCI, check if there is an option to disable onboard video too,
My bios has the option, but ubuntu can only boot to my board-integrated otherwise my xserver crashes
xserver crashes means you've successfully chaged video devices though
So how can I celebrate my xserver crashes with a nice gui?
so youre question should be how to keep xserver alive
sudo dpkg-reconfigure -phigh xserver-xorg in the command shell after xserver crashes, but remember this may render your working onboard video to an unworking state
yes, I suppose so, but how can I use my far better pci card? I've used SuSe and YAST before, and I could do it there, is there anything like that on ubuntu and if so where?
there's no way to do it besides that? I may need to use my board integrated, though not for ubuntu
the "sudo dpkg-reconfigure -phigh xserver-xorg" command should run you through a video card setup for the xorg.conf file.. after that you can restart X
is there anything I can do with it on to change the card it uses from 0 to 1?
if the onboard video is unworkable after that.. just reset bios to use onboard video and run "sudo dpkg-reconfigure -phigh xserver-xorg" again
someone else may have a better idea.. that would be my first try though
how would I access xserver with it running on command line? I remember how to do it, I just was able to get to it easier on SUSE
also, if I were installing most of the rpg's that came with edgy, would I experience what looked like a crash on the part of the package manager?

I've seen software that edits the bios from the OS end.. but it's been so long i dont remember.. and to access X from the command you simply type sudo /etc/init.d/gdm restart or /etc/init.d/kdm restart ( kdm for kubuntu) ( gdm for ubuntu )
thanks, I'll be implementing that now. thanks for helping a noob!

the default package manager defaults to international repository.. which for would stall out and look like a crash maybe for those using synaptic.. enable repositories to use United State server fixes this
